title: Marks & Spencer expands free click-and-collect days after John Lewis introduces charge
text:
8.51 0.00 
The retailer is rolling out the service to 100 more outlets in a bid to widen its market share 
Marks & Spencer (Other OTC: MAKSF - news ) this week will start rolling out free in-store collection at more than 100 of its Simply Food outlets in motorway service stations, railways, hospitals and airports, making it even easier for customers to shop online. 
The first new collection points will include Simply Food stores at King's Cross, Manchester Piccadilly and Cardiff Central railway stations. 
Collection from Heathrow Terminals One, Two, Three and Five, as well as sites at Gatwick, Luton, Birmingham, Edinburgh and Stansted airports will be available later this summer. 
The announcement comes just days after rival John Lewis said that it would start charging customers £2 to collect online orders in store , citing "unsustainable" and "bonkers" web-based business models. 
However, free collection is popular with M&S shoppers, with over half of orders from the website picked up in-store, said David Walmsley, director of M&S.com. 
"By extending the service to locations such as railways and service stations, which may form part of customers’ daily journey, we hope to make it even easier and more convenient for them to shop with M&S," he said. 
Under the new scheme, shoppers will be able to order online and collect their goods at Simply Food stores run by M&S' franchise partners SSP and Moto. 
John Lewis is to charge customers who use its click-and-collect service 
UK-listed catering firm SSP operates Simply Food stores on behalf of M&S, predominantly in travel centres, such as train stations, airports and hospitals. Moto runs Simply Food outlets at motorway service stations. 
M&S has already introduced click-and-collect to its 200 wholly owned Simply Food stores and to its 300-strong store estate. 
This agreemeent will see 100 franchise stores added to the click-and-collect network. 
However, consumers will be limited to what they can order. The service only extends to clothing, accessories and smaller homeware items. 
With consumers increasingly choosing to shop over the internet, the UK's high-street retailers have been battling it out for market share by introducing ever-shorter delivery options and cut-off times for online shoppers. 
But many industry experts have questioned the profitability of online shoppping and believe a number of well-known high-street names actually subsidise the service. 
Amazon operates a slick and sophisticated delivery service 
It hasn't helped that online-only players have upped the ante: last month, cyber behemoth Amazon cranked up the pressure on high-street rivals by offering a one-hour delivery service. 
That has prompted John Lewis to become the first department store in the UK to charge a fee for in-store collection. 
The move could prove to be a significant point in the evolution of online retail as businesses debate how to wring more profits from online shopping. 
Andy Street, managing director of John Lewis, had previously pointed to the collapse of delivery firm City Link last Christmas as evidence that “illogical” business models have to change for retailers and logistics groups. 
Last month Sainsbury’s and Tesco (Xetra: 852647 - news ) axed their click-and-collect points at selected London Underground stations amid claims that they were being used by motorists rather than the Tube passengers who were supposed to use them. 
M&S boss Marc Bolland is under pressure to around the British retailing giant 
Meanwhile, Marks & Spencer is set to unveil quarterly results on the morning of its annual general meeting at Wembley Stadium on Tuesday. 
The expectation is for a slide in like-for-like sales in the crucial general merchandise division. The setback is expected to be painful for chief executive Marc Bolland who, just a few weeks ago, pointed to a recovery of clothing sales in the last quarter as a sign that his turnaround was beginning to pay off.
